text: TWO BOYS sit on opposite sides of a chessboard.  One is N the other FOURTEEN.  The room is SILENT, the tension betw the two young players severe.  All the ADULT PLAYERS that been eliminated from this match by the two boys stand aro watching.  On the wall is a BANNER that reads:  1972 WASH STATE TOURNAMENT.

The FOURTEEN year old moves and hits his TIMER.  Frustrat fills the NINE year old's face.  He moves.  The FOURTEEN old moves and calls CHECK.  The NINE year old frantically searches the board for a solution.  He moves.  Again the FOURTEEN year old moves and calls CHECK.  The NINE year i stunned.  He picks up his KING to lay it on it's side and signal defeat.  Suddenly, he rakes the pieces off the boa grabs his fountain pen and lunges at the FOURTEEN year ol stabbing him repeatedly in the chest.  They fall to the f The ADULTS try to pull them apart.  The NINE year old str ferociously, SCREAMING and kicking like a mad man.
In the b.g. we see the Nine year old Boy sleeping.  A DOC and the boy's FATHER, a hard-looking MAN in his forties, through the door.  We MOVE with them down the hall.
The pressures and demands players with your son's abilities put on themselves to win are incredible.  The stress and tension are difficult enough for adults to handle, yet alone a nine year old.
I can't afford to keep him in here forever, you know.
I'd just like to keep him here over night, then start sessions with a child psychologist.
I knew this would happen.  This is his mother's doing.  She's not strict enough with him.  I work all day.  She lays in bed drunk and the boy does whatever he wants.
After he's released it's crucial that he's supervised.  The most important thing is that during his treatment he's not allowed anywhere near a chessboard.
A small, tract home.  The Boy sits on the ground, drawing the dirt with a stick.  He does not notice as his Father up and stands behind him.
What are you doing?
The Boy is startled.  He stands up quickly.  In the DIRT he has drawn a CHESSBOARD.
Nothing.
The Father SLAPS him across the face.
Don't lie to me!  What did the doctor's tell you about playing chess!  Get in the house!
The Father drags his foot across the dirt, erasing the bo
The Boy is sitting on his bed.  In the b.g. we HEAR the V of his PARENTS.
I've had it!  I've got a drunk for a wife and a lunatic for a son.  I don't need this shit anymore!
We HEAR FOOTSTEPS.
You're crazy!  Both of you.
We HEAR a DOOR SLAM.  The Boy shows no sign of emotion.

All is quiet except for a faint DRIPPING SOUND.  A door i slowly opened.  Light streaks out into a hallway.  We see NINE year old.  He is barefoot and wearing pajamas.  He l up.  Drops of BLOOD drip from a crack in the ceiling abov The Boy moves towards a staircase at the end of the hall.
The Boy enters, takes a few steps into the room and stops stares ahead blankly.

The arm hangs off the bed, blood flows out of a deep gash her wrist and pools on the floor.  The CAMERA moves up th A WOMAN in her forties lays in bed.  The blood flows from other wrist, soaking into the mattress.  Her eyes are clo head titled away from him.

The Boy shows no sign of emotion.  He walks over to the nightstand and starts to open her purse.  There is a MOAN the WOMAN as she opens her eyes and turns her head toward boy.  They lock eyes for a moment, then slowly, her eyes The boy removes a key from the purse and walks to a dress He unlocks a drawer and removes a box, then leaves the ro

The Boy walks over to the table with a glass of MILK and COOKIES.  He sits down, his feet dangling from the chair opens the box.  Inside is a CHESSBOARD and PIECES.  He re them, sets up the board and starts to play.
CLOSE ON CHESSBOARD:  The CAMERA moves from one side of t board to the other, weaving through the chess pieces, the PULLS BACK over the heads of the AUDIENCE.
>From the rear of the room, over the HEADS of the AUDIENC see THREE TABLES on stage.  A large board of the game is presented on the wall behind each table.
CLOSE SHOT - PLAYER'S EYES:  We cut back and forth.  Deep probing eyes, intensely focused and determined.
CLOSE ON THE CLOCK: It ticks methodically, and is the onl sound we hear.
THE AUDIENCE:  watches with anticipation, their eyes lock the viewing board.

PETER SANDERSON sits on one side of the board.  He is a handsome man, in his early thirties.  Well-dressed in an expensive suit, there is an air of confidence about him. makes a move, then hits the timer.  Peter's opponent, GRANDMASTER LUTZ, a quirky-looking little man in his fift makes a tentative move.
JEREMY EDMONDS, Peter's trainer, a distinguished-looking his fifties, watches from his WHEELCHAIR.  He grins and n his head, knowing that Peter has got the game.

Lutz studies the board, makes a move, then hits his timer Peter moves, then hits his timer.  He is in control. Frustration shows on Lutz's face.  He surveys the board, slowly reaches over and lifts up his KING and lays it on side signaling defeat.  Peter stands, shakes his hand, wa the crowd, then leaves the stage.
A NEWSCASTER is positioned by the stage door.

Today concludes the second week of competition in this round-robin candidates tournament.  Each of the players will play four games against the other and the winner will earn the right to play for the world title next year.
Peter walks through the doorway and down the hall, accept congratulations.  Jeremy wheels himself along side of him

But the big story is the amazing comeback of Peter Sanderson who is currently leading the tournament. America's best hope since Bobby Fischer, Sanderson stunned the chess world three years ago when he walked out in the middle of last candidates tournament while leading by three games and forfeited the match to Viktor Yurilivich who is only two games behind Sanderson in this match.
Peter stops to sign a few autographs.  A young attractive in her twenties walks over to Peter.  She is wearing a CH FEDERATION BLAZER and a NAME TAG identifying her as DEBI RUTLEGE.
Mister Sanderson, here is your schedule for tomorrow.
Peter takes it.  They lock eyes.  She smiles at him.  A REPORTER sticks a MICROPHONE in Peter's face.
Peter, could we have a moment please?
The moment is broken, as ERICA SANDERSON, Peter's daughte bright-faced ten year rushes up to him and hugs him.
Congratulations, dad.
(to the press)
My cheering section.
Peter sits across a CHESSBOARD from Jeremy, who has just finished making an opening move.
You opened with the English.  Lutz won't use it.  He opened his first game with it.
He knows you're aware of that.
Then I'll transpose.
On a variation, yes -- but it must be a variation that is unique.
I suppose you have something in mind?
Peter gets up and begins to pace.
(quickly moving the pieces)

At this point you'll move Bishop to e4. He'll capture your Knight e6.  Rook to b5, begins his counterplay.  D6 takes your Rook, your advantage is lost -- but watch -- Queen f5 check.  He takes your Knight -- Now, Rook to d3 -- he's finished.
There is a KNOCK on the door and a MESSAGE is slipped und Peter picks it up.
It's a good play, but risky.
You don't win by playing it safe, Peter.
Peter opens the MESSAGE and reads it.  Erica appears in t doorway to her room.
What are you doing up?
I can't sleep.  My beds lumpy.
I see.  You forgot to bring you're night-light, didn't you?
That has nothing to do with it.
You want to sleep in my bed tonight?
Okay.
I'll tuck you in.
Erica kisses Peter, then runs into his room.  Jeremy whee after her.
Jeremy, have someone pick up a night- light tomorrow.
Jeremy nods and leaves the room.  Peter picks up the phon dials.
(into phone)
Debi..?

Peter and Debi move passionately on the bed, their bodies moving rhythmically.  Peter pulls her up to a sitting pos guiding her up and down as he runs his lips sensually ove breasts.  She arches her back, MOANING softly as she give to her pleasure.
Peter kisses Debi goodbye.  He walks off and she closes t door.
Debi is soaking in the bath.  The DOORBELL RINGS.
Debi slips on a ROBE as she walks to the door.
Yes?
(static; barely audible)
It's me.  I forgot something.
She smiles and pushes the button, then opens the door, le it ajar, and walks out of the room.
Debi quickly fixes her face, grins and leaves.
It is dark.  She enters and tries the light switch.  It d work.
Very funny.
CLOSE ON DEBI:  She senses something is very wrong.  She around slowly, her eyes squinting to see through the dark Suddenly, terror fills her face as a FLASH of BRIGHT LIGH fills the screen.

Quaint and charming.  Boats bob lazily in the water.  TOU walk along the waterfront shops.  ANDY WAGNER, a tough-lo cop in his twenties, smokes a cigarette as he waits on th dock.  CHIEF OF POLICE, FRANK SEDMAN, walks towards him. a large, slightly over-weight man in his forties.  He tak last drag of a cigar, then crushes it out on the dock.
Sorry to ruin your trip to the city, but we got a real nut on our hands, Frank.
(all business)
Run it down.
Frank starts to walk.  Andy follows.
(looking at note-pad)
Debi Rutlege.  Female.  Caucasian. Twenty four.  Worked over at the Four Oaks Hotel.
Local?
No.  She just moved here last month from Portland.
Several BLACK and WHITE units are in front of the buildin Uniformed OFFICERS keep back a CROWD of onlookers.  A CAR drives up and stops in front of the building.  Frank and get out.
The room is filled with FORENSIC TEAM MEMBERS along with UNIFORM OFFICERS.  Frank enters with Andy.  UNIFORMED OFF are standing around talking.
This isn't a party.  Everybody that doesn't need to be here get out!
Frank enters the room with Andy.  He stops and stares at sight before him.

Debi Rutlege is laying on her bed.  Her face is a deathly and has been painted awkwardly with rouge and lipstick gi her a macabre appearance.  She is draped in the sheet whi tucked tightly around her body, her hands folded carefull across her chest.
Above the bed written in blood is REMEMBER.
I moved out here from the city so I could get away from this kind of shit.
STEVE NOLAN, from the forensic team, who has been kneelin the other side of the bed stands up.
Whaddaya got, Nolan?
(continuing; holding up a plastic bag)
Not much.  There's no sign of a break in.  I think she let him in.
How long has she been dead?
Six, eight hours tops.
Any sign of rape?
Not that I can see.  We'll know more once I get the lab reports back from Seattle.
What she die of?
Nolan turns over her arms.  There are deep gashes in each wrist.
You think whoever did this wanted it to look like it was a suicide?

No.  He would have taken more care not to the leave rope burns on her wrists. The way I got it figured is he tied her up, slit her wrists, then sat back and watched her bleed to death.  But that's not the main thing.  What's wrong with this picture?
A beat.  Suddenly, Frank sees it.
There's no blood.  Where's the fuckin' blood?
Bingo.
Frank and Andy walks across the yard.
Who found her?
Andy points to MISS GREENWELL, a middle-aged woman talkin UNIFORMED OFFICER in the b.g.
The landlady.  Alice Greenwell.  She came for the rent check.  The door was ajar.
Frank walks over to Miss Greenwell.
Miss Greenwell, I'm Captain Sedman. Did Miss Rutlege have a boyfriend?
I guess so.
What do you mean, you guess so?
I know she had company last night. (confidentially)
A man.
How do you know that?
Well, her bedroom is on the other side of mine.  The walls are very thin.  I could hear them.
What were they doing?  Humping?
They were having sex, yes--
Andy grins.
-- not that I was intentionally listening -- but  with the walls being so thin--
I understand.  Thank you.
Frank and Andy stand before several UNIFORMED OFFICERS.

First of all, I'd like to say that a lot of us haven't got to know each other since I replaced Captain Waters last month.  A lot of you think that I'm an outsider who came over and took away a job that should have gone to a local... but that's the way it worked out.  So, all I can say is tough shit. You want to bitch about it, that's fine -- but you will tow the line in my department.  That means the next time an Officer is responding to a homicide call he seals off the crime scene and nobody -- nobody but  but Detective Wagner and I go in. (Beat)
Also, if anyone talks about the message on the wall or the blood I'll personally cut their balls off with a butter knife. (to Andy)
Get 'em going - then meet me at the car.  We're going over to the hotel.
Frank heads to the door.
Campbell, you check with the FBI see if they got anything like this on file...
Frank steps into the hall and bumps into Nolan.  They wal together.
Anything?
Not much.  I don't think she was raped. There's no bruising, or any signs of trauma to the pelvic region -- and no trace of sperm which makes sense because she took a bath.
What about prints?
No prints.
You mean, no prints but hers?
No Frank.  No prints.
Peter is sitting at a chessboard with Jeremy.  Peter stud the board.  There is a KNOCK on the door.  Peter gets up opens the door.  Frank and Andy are outside.
Mister Sanderson?  I'm Frank Sedman, Bainbridge P.D. and this is Detective Wagner.  We'd like to ask you a few questions about Debi Rutlege.
Peter opens the door and they enter.
I know you're busy so I'll get right to it.  Did you know her?
Only in passing.  To say hello to.
I've talked to a few people who say you and her were... friendly?
Chess tournaments can be boring sometimes.  People have a lot of free time.  They like to gossip.
Could you tell me where you were last night?
Here.  I played Gregory Lutz.
I know.  You won two games against him and left the auditorium at eight forty five.  Where did you go after that?
To my room and then I went for a walk.
By yourself?
Yes.
Frank takes out a piece of paper from his jacket pocket.
This is a printout from the hotel computer for all the messages logged to your room.  Here's one at 9:04 pm.  It says:  From Debi.  Please call me at home.
She called to give me my schedule for tomorrow.

What's interesting about it is you say you only knew her in passing.  Yet, she says on her message for you to call her at home and she doesn't leave a number. That would imply you already knew the number.
I got it from the tournament directory.
Frank takes out a small book.
There's no Debi Rutlege listed in the directory.
Peter's irritation starts to show.  He opens a dresser dr and removes a small book.
You're looking in the general directory.  The player's directory lists everyone connected to the tournament.
A beat.  Frank and Peter have reached a stalemate.
We seem to have a little problem here?
What kind of problem?
I think you're lying.  That's what kind of problem.
What are you saying?
We're not saying anything right now. We're just trying to put a few pieces together.
Frank and Andy leave.  Peter turns and stares at Jeremy.
Frank and Andy walk along the grounds, heading back towar main hotel.
What do you think?
He's got an answer for everything, but he doesn't have an alibi.
You think he's dirty?
I don't know, but I think you're right. He's lying.

On the stage is three tables each flanked by two chairs. Several CHESS OFFICIALS along with the PRESIDENT of the C FEDERATION attend to the GRANDMASTERS at their respective boards.  Peter sits in a chair and swivels back and forth
I want another chair.  This one killed me yesterday. (points to big board)
Also, the pieces on the board move too slowly.  I can see them out of the corner of my eye.  Can they be sped up?
David?
DAVID WILLERMAN, a computer technician sits at a computer to the side of the stage.
No problem.  It's just a matter of adjusting the response time.
He taps in a few commands on the keyboard.  We see a piec quickly move across the board.
That should do it.
Grandmaster Lutz walks over and stands by the board.
You're acting like a superstitious schoolboy, Peter.  What's next? Incense and rosary beads?
(points to a chair)
Grandmaster Lutz, you'll be sitting here for your next match.
Oh no -- no, I can't sit there.  I must be facing North.  My power comes from the North.
Peter smiles and starts to walk off stage.  VIKTOR YURILI a tall, slender man in his forties, walks on stage.  The men stand face to face, their eyes locked on each other.
Hello, Peter.  You played an interesting game last night.  Even though sacrificing your Queen at b-5 is the game I played against Valsney in '82.  I'm glad it helped you.
I'm sure you are.
No, I want you to do good.  That way when I beat you at the end I'll look that much better.
You're getting sloppy, Yurilivich. You're nervous?
I'm not nervous.
Well, you should be, because this time I'm going to win.
Well, then this time you'll have to stay for the whole match, won't you?
Peter sits at a table across from Erica.  They play a gam checkers as they eat their ice cream.  Peter is grinning.
Who told you that?
Mrs. Lutz.  She also told me that Mr. Lutz goes to a medium to try and contact great Grandmasters in the spirit world.
Has he gotten through to any?
No, but he did contact a dead parcheesi champion from Ohio.
They both LAUGH.  A WAITER comes over with a CORDLESS PHO
There's a call for you Mister Sanderson.
(into phone)
Hello?
The "CALLERS" VOICE we HEAR is FILTERED through some type electronic devise that alters the voice.  It is low, reso with a macabre quality to it.
Hello, Peter.
Who is this?
Someone who's going to become an important part of your life. (Beat)
I want to play a game with you.
I haven't got time for this.
Peter starts to hang up, when...
You had time for Debi.
Peter freezes.
Don't worry, I wiped off all your prints.
Peter slowly lowers the phone back on the cradle.  He is visibly shaken.
What is it, dad?
Nothing.
As Peter walks across the room the DESK CLERK calls out t
Mister Sanderson, there's message for you.
Peter walks over to the desk.  The Clerk hands him an env Peters walks away and starts to open it.

CLOSE SHOT:  The back of a POLAROID PHOTOGRAPH.  Letters been clipped out of a magazine and spell out a message: GAME HAS BEGUN.  WILL CALL AGAIN TOMORROW AT ELEVEN.  The photograph is turned over.  It is a shot of DEBI RUTLEGE exactly as the police found her.  The word REMEMBER writt the wall.  Peter slides the picture back into the envelop thinks for a moment, then looks at the DESK CLERK.
Get me the police.
Peter is with Frank and Andy.
Why didn't you tell us you were there earlier?
I don't know.  I was afraid there'd be hours of questions.  I can't afford to miss a game.
We wouldn't want someone's death to interfere with your games.
What was your relationship with her?
Casual.
Casual?  You were boning her weren't you?
It wasn't serious.  What's your problem?
You are!  I don't like you.
Fine, don't ask me out on a date.
Don't worry I won't.  I've seen how your dates end up.
Peter takes a step towards Andy.  They both square off.
Take it easy.  Both of you.
I'm sorry, this is just too convenient.
What's that supposed to mean?
It means, if I were a killer and I thought the police were closing in on me I might invent someone to try and put them off the scent.
That's crazy!  Why would I draw attention to myself like that?
You like to play games, don't you, Peter?
He says on the photo he'll call tomorrow at eleven.  Why not come back then and listen for yourself.
Oh, we'll be back.  You can bet on it.

Peter sits across from GRANDMASTER LUTZ.  He looks over a tables and stares at Yurilivich.  Meanwhile, Lutz takes o compass.  He checks his reading then starts shifting the slightly.  Peter looks at him.
Do you mind?
Peter shrugs his shoulders indicating he doesn't.  The President walks over to Peter's table and starts his time Peter makes a move.
Frank and Andy sit at a table with DOCTOR ALAN FULTON.  A thin man in his fifties.  Doctor Fulton studies the photographs, then looks up at Frank.
You must understand that this is not my field?
It ain't mine either but I can tell this guy's crazy.  That's your business ain't it, doc?  You deal with crazy people.
I deal with people with problems... and there are all different types of problems.
Doctor Fulton, we don't have a budget out here like Seattle.  We can't afford to hire outside Psychological help. I'll take whatever you can give me.
Well, he appears to be acting out some kind of fantasy.  We're talking about a deeply disturbed person.
No shit!
Could someone this disturbed give the appearance of being normal?
Absolutely.
We've got a suspect but no hard evidence.  If you met him do you think you could tell?
Tell what?
If he's crazy?
(askance at Andy)
If he's... disturbed.
It's possible, but not likely.  There's only one opinion I can offer with any certainty. (Beat)
He's going to kill again.

Peter is on the bench press straining to finish his set. Although he is clearly tired, it's a battle of will over muscle.  Although his face is red, veins bugling, he does three last presses, then replaces the bar.  He sits up an buries his face in his towel.  When he looks up he sees..
KATHY SHEPPARD, a beautiful woman in her twenties is stan against the wall, her eyes on him.  Peter smiles at her. smiles back, then walks out of the room.  Peter lays back and starts another set.
Peter enters, a towel wrapped around his waist.  He takes steps into the room, then stops when he sees Kathy throug steam.
Sorry.  I thought it was empty.
It's alright.
Peter sits down a few feet from her.  Steam swirls throug room.  Kathy's eyes drift over to him.
HER POV:  Beads of sweat roll down his chest and stomach.

Peter looks over at her, their eyes meet.  She looks away Peter closes his eyes and takes a few deep, meditative br Kathy looks over at him again.  As if sensing he is being watched Peter opens his eyes.  A beat.  Their eyes linger each others.
Is this your first time here?
Yes.
I love this hotel.  I stay here every time I visit my parents.
How come you don't stay with them?
Because I love them, but they drive me crazy.  You know how parents are?
No.  I don't.
A beat.
Are you with the tournament?
Uh huh.
Are you one of the players?
Yes.
I've always wanted to learn how to play chess.  I don't have the patience for it.  When did you start playing?
When I was very young.
It seems like such a complicated game.
Not really.  You see your goal and you go after it.  Anything that gets in the way is an obstacle and must be destroyed.
Sounds very violent.
Chess is a reflection of life.  Life is violent.  The strong win.  The weak perish.
--but you enjoy being the stronger one? You like the control.
If you're asking me if I'm passionate about what I do, the answer is yes. Without passion, nothing moves us. What's your passion?
That's a very personal question.
I see.  This is going to be a very polite conversation.  What shall we discuss?  The weather?  Movies?
Are you disappointed that I won't answer you?
I had just hoped there would be more substance to the conversation.
I thought opening too quickly was a fatal mistake in chess.
(grinning)
It is.
Do you always open quickly?
Are we talking about me, or chess?
You.
Each circumstance requires a different tactic.
Well, I hope you remember that tomorrow when you play Krikorian.
Peter stares at Kathy for a moment.  She's made a mistake she knows it.  She stands up.
Well, I think I've had enough.
Getting too hot in here for you?
She feigns a smile and starts towards the door.  Suddenly hand shoots out, grabbing her arm.  She freezes.  Peter s up, his body trapping her between him and door, his lips touching her ear.
What are you looking for?
Nothing.  I just came in for a steam.
No you didn't.
He spins her around.  They are face to face.
What are you?  A reporter?  Just how far were you going to go?
A beat.  Peter lets her go and backs off.  She opens the and leaves.  Peter smiles.
Kathy walks across the grounds.  Frank catches up with he walks along side.
Well?
Well what?  I told you this was a stupid idea.  You can't learn anything from someone in a few minutes.
You didn't pick up any vibes from the guy?
I'm a psychologist, Frank... not a psychic.  What's this all about anyway?
What did Dr. Fulton tell you?
Only that you wanted someone from the institute to talk to Sanderson for some case you're working on.  What'd he do?
We're not sure.
What do you think he did?
We think he could be a suspect in a murder investigation.
Kathy stops dead in her tracks and stares at him.
The girl that was killed last night?
Frank's silence tells her she's right.  She stares at him moment, then walks off.
Kathy is BANGING loudly on the front door.  A moment late is answered by Dr. Fulton.  In the b.g a DINNER PARTY is on.
Dr. Fulton sits on the couch.  Kathy paces the room.
You might not have done it had you known.
You're damn right!  I'm a child psychologist and you send me into a room with someone who could be a murderer!
Would you mind keeping your voice down? I have guests.
Oh, well we wouldn't want to disturb your guests, would we?
The police came to me for help.  What could I do?
You could have been honest with me for starters.  We work together.  I have to be able to trust you.
(checks his watch)
I admit I handled it badly.  Sanderson wasn't going to talk to me... but you're young, attractive--
--the same type as the girl who got killed.  Jesus, Alan, the guy could be a psychopath.
They asked who would be best suited for this and you--
Don't patronize me!  You sent me into a potentially dangerous situation and didn't warn me!
She walks to the door and opens it.
It worked out alright, didn't it?
(loudly)
Fuck off!
All the GUESTS are sitting at the dinner table, eating so They stare at Kathy.  Fulton.
(to the guests)
That's what I would have said to the chef if I caught him shaving over the soup.
She walks out.  Slowly, several of the GUESTS lower the s spoons and push their bowls away.
The LOBBY appears empty.  One of the office doors opens a CHRISTIE EASTMAN, A young, attractive woman, comes out ca a stack of files.  She walks out of the lobby, LOCKING th behind her.
As the car descends, Christie looks through one of the fi She turns a page and the file falls to the floor.  She be down to pick it up.  As she does the elevator stops and t doors open.

A pair of black boots stand before her.  She looks up to MAN in his fifties.  He smiles and gets in.  The doors cl and the car starts down again.  Christie stares at the fl indicator, somewhat unnerved by the man's presence.  The stops at the lobby and the man gets out.
Christie walks across the deserted parking lot towards he She HEARS a SOUND and stops and looks around.
CHRISTIE'S POV:  As her eyes scan the desolate parking lo sees nothing unusual.
Christie starts to walk again.  She arrives at her car, g inside, then rolls down the window.
Christie starts the car, then takes out a cigarette from pocket and lights it.  She takes a deep drag, then looks into...
CLOSE ON REAR VIEW MIRROR:  From the back seat we see TWO EYES staring at her from behind a PORCELAIN MASK.
She turns around.  Her face filled with fear.  FLASH!  Th screen is filled with BRIGHT LIGHT.
A car drives up the gravel path and stops in front of the entrance.  Frank gets out and walks towards the door.
Kathy is watching a young GIRL through a two-way mirror i next room as she plays and interacts with dolls and toys. makes a few notes, then the door opens and Frank walks in
I'm busy right now.
It's important.

Kathy goes through a door into the observation room.  Thr the mirror we see her kneel down next to the girl and smi She says something to her as she points to a door leading of the room.  The girl gives her a big hug.  A moment lat see Frank join her in the room.  He says something and th start to argue.  Kathy points towards the door.
CLOSE ON COMPUTER MONITOR:  A chess program.  A piece is The screen reads:  CHECKMATE!  YOU WIN.  PULL BACK.
Peter is at the computer.  Jeremy sits beside him.  Frank over to Andy who is with a TECHNICIAN setting up tracing equipment.
We're all set.
I still think this is a crock of shit.
There's a KNOCK at the door.  Andy opens it.  Kathy enter
I'm glad you could make it.
Peter looks at Frank, then Kathy with confusion.
Mister Sanderson, this is Doctor Sheppard.  She's a psychologist helping us out.
We've already met.  Haven't we... Doctor.
(she smirks)
I see you're still having problems with your openings.
And this Jeremy--
--Edmonds.  I know.  You lost to Karpov in '82, didn't you?
Yes.  However, that's not exactly how I prefer to be remembered. (Beat)
Well, I'm going to get out of your way. Peter, I'll see you this afternoon.
CLOSE ON ASHTRAY:  A cigarette is snuffed out.  PULL BACK Andy finishes putting out his cigarette, then glances up Peter who is pacing back and forth.  Andy checks his watc
Eleven oh six.
He looks at Peter with a grin.  A beat as the two men sta each other.  The moment is broken as the PHONE RINGS LOUD Peter's head snaps towards the phone.
Remember, try to keep him on as long as you can.  Don't confront him.  Let him answer the questions I gave you.
The Technician starts his tape machine and tracing equipm Peter picks up his CORDLESS PHONE.
Hello?
We HEAR the CALLER'S distorted VOICE.
Hello, Peter.
(stalling)
Just a second. (a beat, then)
Hello?
Very amateurish, Peter.  I'm surprised you would use such an obvious tactic. (there is anger in his voice)
I'm not an idiot!  Don't treat me as one!  I'll call you everyday... You get one minute, whether you put me on hold or talk is up to you!  Are you ready to play?
Yes.  Why did you kill Debi Rutlege?
To get your attention.
Did you know her?
No, only the path she chose to travel.
Peter is trying to keep the conversation moving.
And -- what path is that?
We all have paths to follow.  You hope yours will lead you to me.
Why did you write remember on the wall?
That's something you'll have to figure out for yourself.  Really, Peter, you can't expect me to answer such direct questions.
Why not?
You don't want to think and that's why I'll win!  I'm already two points ahead.
What?
I did another one last night.  You might have saved her, but you didn't want to play.
Where is she?
You'll find her.
If you got something to say to me, just come out and say it!
Andy picks up the extension phone.
Where is she you sonofabitch!
There's a chuckle from the Caller.
Ah... Detective Wagner.  I'm sorry but you'll have to get off the line and go back to your tracing equipment.  If I wanted to play the game with a moron I would have called you.
Frank angrily motions Andy to get off.  Andy hangs up.
I suppose you want to know where I'm going to kill tonight, Peter?
You're not going to tell me that.

"Wee Willie Winkie runs through the town.  Upstairs and downstairs in his nightgown.  Crawling through the window.  At the end of Miss Emma's street.  Her God has gone and left his home.  So her and I can meet."
The line goes dead.  A beat.  Everyone reflects on what t have just heard.
(to Andy)
Are you out of your fuckin' mind picking up the phone!
Sorry.
(to Technician)
Anything?
Nothing.  We'd have a better chance if we could tap in at the junction box.
Thanks Mister Sanderson. (to Kathy and Andy)
Let's go.
You want me to go with you?  Maybe I can help.
That's alright.  We'll take it from here.
Kathy, Frank and Andy leave Peter's room and walk back to the hotel.
You should be an actor, Frank.  You looked like you were really mad.  The veins popping out on your neck was a really nice touch.
You weren't mad at him for picking up the phone?
No.  I told him to.  I wanted to make sure there was someone on the other end.
But we heard him.
It could have been a tape.  A prerecorded conversation between Sanderson and himself.
A room set up to deal with the murder.  PHOTOGRAPHS are p to a cork board.  Frank is at a table with Kathy, Andy an Nolan.  On the chalkboard in the rhyme the Caller recited earlier.
The F.B.I. has nothing remotely similar to this guy.  I think he's a first- timer.
Check with the State.  If he's never killed outside of Washington the F.B.I. wouldn't have it.  Nolan?

He tapes their mouths shut.  We found traces of adhesive around the victims mouths.  We're doing a chemical analysis for components, but it's probably a standard brand you can buy in any hardware store.
There's only two hardware stores on the whole Island.  We'll check that out. What about the blood?
Not a drop.  Maybe the guy works for the Red Cross.
Frank looks at Nolan askance.
Kathy?
Well, the fact that he views this as a game suggests that he is trying to prove some sense of superiority -- and the way he murders confirms a need to be in complete control of his victim.
What about the way he arranged the body?

That would indicate he's playing out a fantasy.  Power-control killers usually fantasize about their actions long before they commit them.  Once they become a reality though, they reach a sense of euphoria and need to repeat the act to sustain it.  But, in all the research I've read on Serial Killers, I've never heard of one moving so fast. It's as if the game is the catalyst for the murders -- not the other way around.
Anything else?
Yes.  Why disguise your voice if no one knows it?
I was thinking the same thing.  He must be local.  It's logical for him to assume that the police would be there, but he recognized Andy's voice and called him by name. (points to the rhyme)
What about this?
I would think it's some type of clue as to where he's going to kill next?
Why does he call Sanderson?
He's one of the best Chess players in the world.  Who better to play a game with?
(to Andy)
You still having a problem with this?
Yeah, I am.  I think he's playing us. If I was a killer and the police were trying to make a case against me, what better why to draw them off than to put their attention on someone else?
Sending yourself anonymous notes in the mail is one thing -- but who called him today?
I don't know.  Maybe there's two of them.  Maybe he hired some Wino to make the calls.
Maybe you're reaching a bit?  I think Sanderson should be in on this. There's a reason why the killer's calling him.
A UNIFORMED OFFICER KNOCKS and enters.
Captain, we found her.
Several BLACK and WHITE UNITS are parked in the rear of t building.  Frank and Andy walk up the loading dock steps silence.

The body of CHRISTIE EASTMAN is laying on top of a large Her body has been draped tightly with a sheet and her arm folded across her chest.  Her face is deathly white and h been made up with the same clumsy makeup.
Written in blood on the wall behind her is:  EVENTUALLY

Peter paces back and forth waiting for the match to begin Yurilivich is sitting in a chair, watching Peter with a g Peter turns around and almost bumps into Lutz who is wear ridiculous hat with sheets of aluminium foil sticking out
They're trying to control my thoughts. (points to the hat)
Aluminium foil.  It repels the thought rays.]
Peter stares at him.  In the b.g. Kathy enters, looks aro then walks over to Peter.
They couldn't break the riddle.
Did you think it was going to be easy? You think he was going to lay it out at your feet?
We need your help.
I offered my help this morning and Sedman turned me down.
But you're the key.  The one he wants to play the game with.
I can't right now.  I've got a game.
She could be dead after the game.
She could be dead now.
What if she isn't?  Where are your priorities?  You have to think between someone's life and a chess game? (raising her voice)
The girl he killed last night was only twenty one years old!  He dumped her body behind a warehouse like a sack of garbage!
Everyone is now staring at Kathy and Peter who are starin each other.  In the b.g. The President appears.
Gentlemen...

The GRANDMASTERS walk onto stage as Peter and Kathy conti stare at each other.  A beat.  Peter starts to move towar stage.  Kathy takes a step after him.  She takes a envelo from her jacket pocket and puts it into Peter's jacket po
These are for you.

Peter sits across from GRANDMASTER KRIKORIAN.  He makes a then hits his timer.  On the BOARD behind him the move is duplicated.  Krikorian studies the board.  Peter is stari over the AUDIENCE deep in thought.  Krikorian makes a mov hits the timer.  Peter continues to stare, unaware that i his move.  A beat.  All eyes are on him.

Peter turns around and stares at the big board, then walk and makes a move.  Krikorian studies his position.  Peter reaches into his pocket for a cigarette.  He removes the envelope Kathy gave him, then his cigarettes.  A beat.  H stares at the envelope, flicking his finger against it. Krikorian looks up annoyed.  Peter opens the envelope.

He is a struggling to make a decision.  Krikorian makes a move. does not react.  He replaces the PHOTOS and stares at the envelope, then looks up at Krikorian who is watching him. beat.  Peter replaces the envelope in his pocket, then ma move.
Kathy sits with Frank and Andy.  Coffee cups litter with The nursery rhyme is written on the BLACKBOARD and reads:

head_text.subj: WEE WILLIE WINKIE RUNS THROUGH THE STREET,
UPSTAIRS AND DOWNSTAIRS IN HIS NIGHTGOWN
AT THE END OF MISS EMMA'S STREET,
HER GOD HAS GONE AND LEFT HIS HOME,
SO HER AND I CAN MEET.

text: "Her God has gone and left his home?"
Everyone shakes there head indicating they don't understa reference.
Why these girls?  How does he pick them?
Frank points to a LARGE MAP of the CITY on the wall, with RED PINS in different locations.
(pointing to the map)
I don't think it matters.  Last nights victim, Christie Eastman was found in a warehouse on the outskirts of town. The night before, Debi Rutlege was found in the center.
Meaning?
Meaning, it looks like his victims are chosen at random.
No.
Peter is standing in the doorway.  He enters the room.
What do you mean, no?
He says it's a game.  All games have a strategy.
All you gotta do is look at the map.
His victims aren't random.  It only means that they appear to be random. There's a connection, we just have to find it.
Peter turns his attention to the blackboard.
What have you come up with on the riddle?
"Wee Willie Winkie runs though the street."  We think he might be making a reference to himself.
Maybe, but I don't think so.  I think it's just a tease.
Upstairs and downstairs in his night gown -- He could be saying the house he's picked is two stories.
As he approaches a TWO STORY house.  The POV stops moving if to decide which way to go... then goes around the righ of the house.
Peter, Kathy, Frank and Andy continue to unravel the mess
(offering)
"Crawling through the window"... We think that's how he's going to get in?
A crowbar is placed under a window and pried up until the breaks.  We see two GLOVED HANDS open the window.
Peter has taken his jacket off and is pacing the room.  K Frank and Andy stare at the board.
That's it?
We think he might be making a reference to drugs?  Miss Emma is a street term used by junkies for Morphine.
Could Emma be the name of the girl he's going to kill?
We've checked.  There's no one with the last name of Emma on the Island.
Maybe he's going to drug her?
He's killed both girls exactly the same way.  It's almost ritualistic.  Why would he change now?
Morpheus.
What?
Not what -- who.  Morpheus.  The Greek God of dreams.  Look at the next line. "Her God has gone and left his home."
His home would be... Mount Olympus.
Call dispatch.  Double the patrols.  I want that area blanketed.
Frank and Andy rush from the room.

LORAINE OLSEN, a YOUNG, ATTRACTIVE GIRL in her twenties e the room and walks over to the CLOSET as she takes off he jacket.  She reaches for the DOORKNOB when the PHONE RING She hesitates for a moment, deciding whether to open the but decides to answer the phone first.  She walks over an picks it up.
Hello?...  Oh hi Mom...  No I just got in...  No I haven't forgotten. Tomorrow, ten o'clock...  Yes... Yes... Okay, I'll see you in the morning. Bye.
She hangs up, walks back to the CLOSET and opens the door

is a large WALK-IN, the back filled with LONG HANGING DRE that almost reach the floor.  Below them is a row of SHOE neatly aligned on the floor.  Loraine hangs up her jacket takes off her shirt, then puts on a tee shirt.

Loraine finishes brushing her teeth.  She turns off the w but we still HEAR a DRIPPING SOUND.  She looks over at th tub with the SHOWER CURTAINS DRAWN.  She opens the curtai tightly turns the handle to stop the nozzle from leaking.
Loraine sits on the edge of her bed and peels herself out her tight pants.
She enters the closet and hangs up her pants.  As she doe we see: Among the row of shoes is a pair of BLACK HIGH-TO
Loraine starts to leave.  The TENNIS SHOES move forward.
CLOSE ON LORAINE:  A GLOVED HAND reaches over and CLAMPS tightly over her mouth, muffling her SCREAM as,
The CLOSET DOOR is SLAMMED SHUT.  SILENCE.  A FLASH of li fills the frame of the door.
Colorful SHOPS and RESTURANTS line the street.  Peter gra HOT DOG from a VENDOR and takes a big bite, then looks at Kathy.
You sure you don't want to eat something?
I don't think I could.
They start to walk agin.
It's going to be a long night.  It could take hours before we know something.  You should try to eat.
You sound like my mother.
It wasn't intentional.
Does what's going on bother you at all? Or are you just wearing your game face?
I think it's interesting.
Another kind of game?
In a way.
This isn't a game.
Oh, but it is.  He's killing a person everyday and challenging us to catch him.  That's a game.  It has rules and objectives.
How can you look at it so clinically?
Take your average cop.  They deal with death everyday.  If they let emotions get in the way it would cloud their judgement.
That's true -- but the emotion is still there.  They just learn to control it.
What about you?  Aren't there times when a young child is telling you a story so sad you just want to cry?
Of course.
Do you?
(uncomfortable)
Let's change the subject.
Okay.  So, tell me about yourself.  Are you married?
Kathy stops.
How did we get to that subject?
I'm just curious.
(uncomfortable)
I think it's best if we don't ask too many personal questions -- I want to keep things on a professional level.
You mean like in the steam room?
That's not fair!
Are you going to tell me you didn't feel something in there?
Kathy is growing more uncomfortable by the moment.
You're projecting your own desires and reading more into what happened than what actually did.
Very good.  Spoken like a true psychologist.  When confronted with the prospect of your own reality, hide behind quotations.  What is that Masters and Johnson?
The tension breaks.  Kathy smiles.
You have to win every point, don't you?
I just wanted to know if you're involved with anyone? (Beat)
Let me ask you something?  Do your colleagues know if you're involved or not?
Of course.
Why?
Because I work with them.
Aren't you working with me?
Kathy smiles again, amused by Peter's tactics.
No.
You're not?
No -- I'm not involved. (Beat)
And I plan on keeping it that way.
Kathy walks off, leaving Peter staring after her.
Kathy, Frank and Andy are in the room with Nolan.  Nolan his knees at the base of a window.  On the floor beside h a RULER and a SHEET OF RUBBERIZED PAPER.
(proudly)
This is where he forced his way in.  We found some fibers on the windowsill, probably particles of clothing that rubbed off when he climbed through. I'll know more once I get it under the microscope.
(not impressed)
That's great.
Wait, I've saved the best for last. Andy, hit the lights, will you?

Andy looks for the light switch.  Kathy realizes she's st in front of it and moves out of the way.  Andy turns off lights and the room goes dark.  Nolan turns on a FLASHLIG gets down on his knees, then SHINES the LIGHT at a LOW AN across the floor.
THE FLOOR - CLOSE SHOT:  We can clearly see the impressio SHOE PRINT.
It's a tennis shoe.  Pretty old by the individual characteristics.  About a size ten or eleven.  This guy is big.
What's this?
Andy points to a JAGGED LINE in the impression.
Don't know.  Looks like a cut or a gash in the sole of the shoe.  We'll blow it up back at the lab.
Frank, Andy and Kathy follow Nolan towards the bedroom. stops and taps Kathy on the shoulder.
Before we go in I gotta tell you this isn't going to be pretty.
I know that.  I've seen the photo's.
This ain't no photo.
Frank, Andy  and Kathy enter the room.  Loraine's body is laying on the bed, her appearance is like all the others.
On the wall written in blood is: REVENGE.
Kathy stares at the sight, horrified.  She starts to gag runs from the room.
Same as the others?
Yeah.
How long she been dead?
I'd say at least eighteen hours.
That means she was dead before we even finished figuring out the message.
Or before Sanderson ever showed up to help us with the riddle.  He figured it out pretty quick, didn't he?  Maybe it's not to hard if you wrote it.
Peter enters in his SWEATS to find Erica, Jeremy and Davi sitting around a computer.
Good morning.
Erica runs over to him and gives him a kiss.
(to Jeremy)
We got a problem?
Our computer went on the fritz again. David came up to fix it.
Is it serious?
Naw, it's all fixed.  I also loaded up a program that'll analyze your games three hundred percent faster.
Thanks.
Peter walks over to the MONITOR.  A COMPUTER GAME is on.
What's this?
Oh, I put a few games on for your daughter.  I hope you don't mind.
Of course not.
Well, I've got to go over Lutz's room now.  He thinks someone has tapped into his computer and is monitoring his practice games.]
David picks up his bag and starts to leave.
Don't you have something you want to say to David?
Thanks, David.
Your welcome.
David leaves.
You ready?
For what?
You told me you'd take me over to Seattle today.
I'm sorry, honey, I can't.  Not today.
But you promised.
Erica stares at him sadly.
I'll take you.
She forces a smile for Jeremy's sake, then leaves the roo
Peter...
I've got be here for the police when they come.  Then I've got to practise. In case you forgot I'm in the middle of a match right now.
You're always in the middle of a match.
I want to be the best I can.

Sometimes I think you'd rather be the best chess player, than the best father.  Instead of thinking about what kind of day your daughter had, you would rather think about the Sicilian Najdorf opening or a counter to the Tartokover Bondarevsky System. (Beat)
A relationship is not a chessboard. You can't walk away from it and come back whenever you want and still expect all the pieces to be there.

Peter enters from the bathroom wearing only his jeans.  H over to his briefcase and starts to take out a paper.  He stops, then slowly takes out an OLD, WORN, ENVELOPE.  He at it. There is a KNOCK on the door.  Peter replaces the ENVELOPE. He opens the door to find a pale and shaken Kat She walks into  the room.
They found the third girl.  Her name was Loraine Olsen.  I just came from the crime scene.  It was horrible.  How can anybody do something like that? You got anything to drink around here?
Peter walks over to the bar and pours her a brandy.  He b it over to her and sits beside her on the couch.  Kathy g it down.
Relax.
How the hell can I relax after seeing what I just saw.
I know it was bad.
How could you?  Unless you were there.
Their eyes lock for a moment, each probing the others.
Sorry, I didn't mean that the way it sounded.
I know you didn't
You know, Andy thinks you're doing this.
Doesn't that scare you?
No.
Why?
Because I think he's wrong.
Peter takes her hand and holds it in his.  There is a KNO the door.  Peter opens it to find Frank and Andy.
Come with us.
Peter follows Frank and Andy as they walk down a utility hallway.
Damp and dark.  A large cavernous room built under the ho

head_text.subj: SEVERAL SMALLER ROOMS, OR ALCOVES, CONNECT TO THE MAIN RO

text: THROUGH A SERIES OF JOINING DOORS.  FLORESCENT LIGHTS spa the ceiling cast long shadows through the room.  Large wa pipes and electrical mains run across the ceiling.
Frank, Andy, Peter and Kathy enter.  Frank walks over to TECHNICIAN we saw before.  He is setting up his tracing equipment at the main TELEPHONE JUNCTION BOX.
How's it going?
(points to a phone)
While we're down here all calls coming into Mr. Sanderson's room will be routed to extenion 611.  I've also--
The PHONE RINGS.  It echoes through the room.  Peter's fa tenses.  He walks over and picks it up.  A LOUDSPEAKER is activated.
Hello?
Do you know what I'm doing right now, Peter?  I'm looking at the name of the girl I'm going to kill tonight.
You know her?
Not really.
Why her?
(a trace of anger)
Because she's the type.
But you said you didn't know her.
(annoyed)
I know what I said!  She looks just like...
Just like who?
I really wish you'd stop trying to maneuver me.  I find it irritating, not to mention insulting.
I'm just trying to play the game.
You're not playing very well.  There are clues all around you and you keep missing them.
Peter's frustration grows.  He decides to try a different
Listen, if you're just going to call up to gloat, I don't want to hear it!
I'm sure there are other people who would be interested in what I have to say.
Then call them!
Peter slams down the phone.  Kathy, Frank and Andy are st that Peter would end the conversation.
Are you crazy?
Let's see how much he wants to play.
SILENCE fills the room.  Peter stares at the phone expect A moment later it RINGS.  Peter waits and lets it ring. Finally he answers it on the fourth ring.
Just for that no hint today.
Why are you doing this?  You must have some idea of the pain you're causing people.
Pain?  Pain is just a state of mind. It's something you learn to live with. I have.
Kathy hands Peter a note she has written.
(reading the note)
And you want these girls to feel your pain?
Please, I don't want to get into the psychological aspects of my actions. It would detract from the game.
How?
I couldn't say it any better than Huxley.
Huxley's quote also says, "his play is always fair and just."
So is mine, within the framework of my rules.
The line goes dead.  Peter hangs up.
What in the hell do you think you're doing?  Slamming down the phone in the middle of the trace.
You think you're going to catch him on a trace?  Everything he does is planned out well in advance.  The only way we're going to get him is to rattle him -- make him slip up.
You never know how you're going to catch a suspect.
Peter's right, Captain.  He's got to be forced into making a mistake.
We didn't ask for your opinion, Doctor.
Maybe you should.
Peter stares at Andy defiantly.
You don't tell us how to run our investigation.  You got that?
You don't have an investigation without me.  You got that?
The two men lock eyes hostilely.
What were you going to say, Kathy?
Well, I think you have to play to his ego.  He thinks he's superior.  The more secure he feels, the more chances he'll take.
What did he mean by Huxley?
He was referring to a quote by Thomas Henry Huxley. (quoting)

"The chess board is the world, the pieces are the phenomena of the universe, the rules of the game are what we call Nature.  The player on the other side is hidden from us.  We know that his play is always fair, just, and patient.  But also, we know, to our cost, that he never overlooks a mistake, or makes the smallest allowances for ignorance."
Peter and Kathy are sitting on the beach.  Peter draws sq in the sand like a chessboard and starts moving shells an rocks around.  Kathy grins.
Are you playing chess?
Peter smiles like a boy with his hand caught in the cooki

When I was little I'd watch the other kids playing baseball from my room.  In the evening, when their parents would call them in to put their bats and balls away, I'd watch them from my window, forcing, expressions of disappointment, trying to gain another few minutes outside so they could play -- but no one could stop me from playing. (he closes his eyes)

All I had to do was close my eyes and my whole world became a chessboard.  I could see the pieces, and sometimes it felt like if I reached out I could almost touch them.  I ordered them and they obeyed.
Kathy stares at him for a moment, unsure what to make of speech.  Peter opens his eyes, there is a beat as he seem bridge the gap back to this world.  He smiles.
Can you go fifteen minutes without thinking about it?
(thinks for a moment)
No.  But I'm open to distractions.
I'm sure you are.
He smiles at her.  He destroys the pattern in the sand, t her hand and they start walking.
You know, you're not the easiest person in the world to get close to.
You always want to talk about me.  What about you?
Wasn't I just talking about me?
No.  You were talking about chess.
Alright.  What about me?
I dunno.  Where's Erica mother?
She died in a car accident.
I'm sorry.
It's alright.  It was a long time ago.
It must've been very hard on Erica?
It was.
And you?
Peter stops and smiles.
Do you want me to lay down, Doctor?
Kathy grins.
Look, why don't you just come out and ask me what you want to know?
Kathy hesitates.
Was it serious between Debi and me? No.  Have I known a lot of girls like her? (Beat)
None of your business.
Kathy stares at him, almost studying him for a moment.
What?
Have you noticed that every time we start to talk about something serious you start to play games.
I'm not playing a game now.
Yes you are.  You're playing word games.
(defensive)
What is this?
I'm just trying to get to know you, Peter.
What?  By attacking me?

Nobody could attack you.  You set your life up like one of your chessboards. You're impregnable -- but at the same time you've become trapped behind your own defenses.  You're cut off from everyone around you.
What are you talking about?  You don't even know me.
Does anyone?
He starts to walk away.
Are you forfeiting?
He stops dead in his tracks, turns and walks back.
I just don't want to fight with you.
Then show me who you are.
Peter thinks.  There's a seriousness we haven't seen befo
This frightens me -- because I'm starting to feel things I haven't felt in a long time.
You've got to face the things you feel.
(a little grin)
I thought you were the woman who didn't want to get involved.
I said I didn't plan on getting involved.
He moves closer.  She takes a step back.
(moving closer)
What happened to facing the things we feel?
(giving in)
You can turn everything around so easily.  This is not just another game, is it?
No.

They stare at each other, each of them probing the others Peter leans forward and gently kisses her on the lips.  H kisses her again.  Their passion builds until they throw arms around each other and embrace passionately.

Peter pins her against the wall and kisses her.  She wrap legs around his waist as he holds her against the wall. continue to kiss as they move along the wall, knocking pi off the wall.  Peter carries her over to a LARGE CHESSBOA With one hand he sweeps the PIECES off onto the floor, th sits her down on it.  They kiss each other furiously, eac them groping at the others clothing.  Their hands move al each others bodies, exploring, touching, feeling.  He un- buttons her blouse, then kisses her neck, working his way her breasts.  Kathy closes her eyes, submitting to the pl of his touch.
TWO SILHOUETTES.  Bodies intertwined.  The SOUNDS of love making fill the room.
I'm hungry.
Call room service.
A LIGHT COMES on.  Kathy lays next to Peter.  She rolls o and kisses him.
I hate hotel food.  Rondi's Pizza is just down the street.
Fine.
What do you want on it?
(nibbling at her neck)
You.
Would you settle for pepperoni?
If I have to.  I'm going to take a shower.
Peter goes into the bathroom.  Kathy sits up and throws o shirt.  She goes to the desk.  By the phone is a copy of WHITE PAGES.  She starts to look up the number.  In b.g. HEAR the SHOWER.
CLOSE ON PHONE BOOK:  In the middle of the page a name is underlined in RED.  It reads:  RUTLEGE, DEBI
Kathy stares at the name.  A beat.  Slowly she turns thro the pages.
CLOSE ON PHONE BOOK:  The name EASTMAN, CHRISTIE is UNDER The pages are quickly turned again until we see the name LORAINE UNDERLINED.
Kathy is stunned.  She thinks for a second, then gets up starts getting dressed.  In the b.g. we HEAR the SHOWER s
Did you call?
The line was busy.  I'll try again.
She finishes dressing then heads for the door.  She opens door and stops, then looks back.
HER POV: Her PURSE is on the nightstand.
She hesitates, then quickly walks back to get it.  She pi up and starts back for the door when... Peter steps out o bathroom.  He stares at her.
Where are you going?
They're not delivering.  I'm going to go pick up the pizza.
(moving closer to her)
I thought you said the line was busy?
